SE(3) - se(3) functions#

An element of SE(3) represent a transformation matrix in \(\mathbb{R}^3\). Such an element can be generated from an element \(\xi\) in se(3).

As se(3) is a vector space, we are able to do probabilities such as expected value, things that are not possible on a group (i.e., SE(3)).

Elements of se(3) are 4x4 matrices of the form

\[\begin{split}M = \xi^\wedge = \begin{bmatrix} \rho \\ \phi \end{bmatrix}^\wedge = \begin{bmatrix} \phi^\wedge & \rho \\ 0^T & 0 \end{bmatrix},\end{split}\]

where \(\phi^\wedge\) corresponds to the element of so(3) of coordinate \(\phi\). See SO(3) - so(3) functions for details on this operation.

Do note that elements of se(3) are matrices and not vectors. However, we prefer using the coordinates while working with these elements. Refer to wikipedia for a precise definition of these terms.

The (linear) operation \((\cdot)^\wedge\) maps a coordinate to its associated element in se(3).

An element of se(3) is mapped on SE(3) using the exponential function, and an element of SE(3) can be sent to se(3) using the logarithm function. For this mapping to be bijective, the restriction is the same as in SO(3) - so(3) functions. We need to restrict the rotation element \(\phi\) of \(\xi=[\rho^T\, \phi^T]^T\) se(3) in the ball of radius \(\pi\), that is

\[||\phi|| < \pi.\]

Careful: The exponential mapping is not homomorphic, which translates to the inequality

\[\exp(\xi_1^\wedge)\exp(\xi_2^\wedge) \neq \exp(\xi_1^\wedge+\xi_2^\wedge).\]

The true result relies on the Baker-Campbell-Hausdorff formula, that is quite complicated and is an infinite series. However, if one of the component is small, we have the following useful approximation:

\[\exp(\xi_1^\wedge)\exp(\xi_2^\wedge) \approx \exp( [\xi_1+\mathcal{J}(\xi_1)^{-1}\xi_2]^\wedge) \quad\text{if } \xi_2 \text{ is small},\]

where \(\mathcal{J}(\xi_1)\) is the (left) Jacobian of SE(3).

Basic se(3) operations#

liblie.wedge_se3(e)#

Return the matrix \(\xi^\wedge\in\mathfrak{so}(3)\) from its coordinates vector \(\xi\)

Parameters

e – 6x1 coordinates vector to be converted.

Returns

4x4 skew symetric matrix

Return type

numpy.ndarray

liblie.curly_wedge_se3(e)#

Return the matrix \(\xi^\curlywedge\in \text{ad}(\mathfrak{so}(3))\) from its coordinates vector \(\xi\)

Note

It is a shortcut operation needed in Jacobians calculations and other advanced stuff

Parameters

e – 6x1 coordinates vector to be converted.

Returns

6x6 skew symetric matrix

Return type

numpy.ndarray

liblie.vee_se3(M)#

Return the coordinates vector \({\xi}\) such that \(M=\xi^\wedge\), where \(M\in\mathfrak{se}(3)\)

Parameters

M – 4x4 matrix to be converted.

Returns

3x1 coordinates vector

Return type

numpy.ndarray

SE(3) - se(3) mappings#

liblie.logm_se3(T)#

Return the matrix logarithm of a rotation matrix \(R\in SO(3)\)

Note

This function is optimized and its closed-form is exact

Parameters

T – 4x4 transformation matrix \(\in SE(3)\).

Returns

4x4 matrix \(\in\mathfrak{se}(3)\)

Return type

numpy.ndarray

liblie.expm_se3(M)#

Return the matrix exponential of a skew-symetric matrix \(M=\phi^\wedge\in \mathfrak{so}(3)\)

Note

This function is optimized and its closed-form is exact

Parameters

M – 4x4 matrix \(\in\mathfrak{se}(3)\).

Returns

4x4 transformation matrix \(\in SO(3)\)

Return type

numpy.ndarray

Left Jacobian of se(3)#

liblie.jac_se3(e)#

Return the left Jacobian of a matrix \(M=\phi^\wedge\in \mathfrak{se}(3)\)

Note

Refer to Barfoot’s book for further explanations about this notion.

Note

This function is an approximation. A closed form, exact fomula exists but is quite lenghty

Parameters

e – 4x4 matrix \(\in\mathfrak{se}(3)\).

Returns

4x4 transformation matrix \(\in SO(3)\)

Return type

numpy.ndarray

liblie.jac_inv_se3(e)#

Return the inverse of the left Jacobian of a matrix \(M=\phi^\wedge\in \mathfrak{se}(3)\)

Note

Refer to Barfoot’s book for further explanations about this notion.

Note

This function is an approximation. A closed form, exact fomula exists but is quite lenghty

Parameters

e – 4x4 matrix \(\in\mathfrak{se}(3)\).

Returns

4x4 transformation matrix \(\in SO(3)\)

Return type

numpy.ndarray
